text: Dark night.  Most street lights shot out.  Just one or tw the eerie vapor lights left on the block. A MIDDLE-AGED AFRICAN-AMERICAN MAN carries his single bag groceries.  The man listens and watches carefully, as he negotiates the darkness between the few pools of light on street. We won't see his face until he reaches the next pool of light, but he walks with shoulders hunched in fear. Moving down the block, all shops abandoned.  Broken windo Rats.  The man almost trips over a vague shadow passed ou and crumpled in an abandoned doorway.  It's the crackhead saw mumbling himself into the nod-off zone.  He's still faintly singing a part of the bones song as the man passe He stops in the light. And we see it's SHOTGUN: 20 years of fear and loathing et on his face.  He freezes, listening for a second to the crackheads wheezing mumbles - no - it's something else he listening for -- and hearing. From behind him a low wheezy sound, like some huge pantin dog.  He stops.  And it stops.  He walks on and it follow As he hurries to the next pool of light and safety, his e strain for the nearly silent padding and wheezing steadil following. Suddenly, he hears that panting closer and closer until i nearly right behind him.  He starts running, though he ha yet seen anything.  Only heard the mongrel hot on his hee

As he stumbles, careens, and wheezes through the streets alleys, terrified.  Winded, he eventually stops, his hand trembling into his shopping bag, seeking a weapon. And we see the building he's paused beside: Bones' place. Pockmarked by age.  Like the face of some furious old man Now he can almost feel the dog's breath on the back of hi neck...Shotgun spins, whipping a bottle of milk out of th bag and hurling it into the darkness behind him. The bottle smashes against the wall of Bones' building. a second, silhouetted against the now whited wall, the ta too tall, shape of the skinny black dog. Without waiting to see what he hit, Shotgun takes off run to reach his building across the street.  The sound of th dog's nails skittering across the street right behind him -- and he just makes it --
Inside, safe, panting for breath.  Then starts running up stairs...
From outside his third floor window, we see Shotgun run i his apartment, slam down his groceries on the counter, gr an old rifle from under his bed and hurry to his open win

He scan/aims out his window across the street to the now desolate building where Bones once lived.  Finger on the trigger, eyes scanning the shadows for the dog.  Mumbling quotations from the Bible about canines, some of which ar handwritten and taped up on his walls and mirrors:
"Thou shalt not bring a dog into the house of the Lord thy God, for they are an abomination."  Deuteronomy.
Suddenly, something moving on the empty street catches hi eye.

The Black Dog emerging from the shadows in the street.  O first good look at the beast.  Long clawed paws, all teet and tongue and a curved bony rib cage like it hasn't eate 20 years. It's long black head seems almost to be throbbing, moving from within, almost subliminally we see a weirder, demoni more skeletal dog face just beneath the black fur... Or i just the buzzing light from the vapor lamps?
(as he aims his rifle) "They return at evening: snarling like dogs and prowling the city..." Psalms 59, vs. 6...
The dog stands in the pool of light, offering a perfect s Shotgun smiles, aims, and then fires, making --

-- a direct hit!  But the dog doesn't move.  Unfazed.  Th bullet must have missed.  Or else gone right through him. The long-faced dog just looks up at Shotgun like it was laughing at the fool.  And has been for years. Shotgun reaches for the spilled groceries on the counter. Shoving aside bread and canned goods and other edible necessitates, and finds a half-dozen boxes of rifle round He calmly reloads the rifle.  And the sound of another sh echoes in the night over...
Two frat boys, JASON and PALMER, driving a too nice car i too bad part of town.  Palmer at the wheel while Jason ma a call on the cellular.
Great.  Gun shots.
Just a backfire.
Like you'd know.  Face it.  We're lost.
Take a left, no, I mean a right.  Okay, stop for a second.
They stop in the middle of a block.  Jason on the phone.
We're here.  Where the hell are you?
(on phone) Back here.  At the end of the block.
He turns around and sees behind them, TWO GUYS standing o the far corner.  One's on the phone.
(on phone) You got the cash?
You got the shit?
(on the phone) Yeah, but you got to come the rest of the way on foot.  Leave your car and walk over here.
They exit the car, looking all around them with more than touch of paranoia. As they walk nervously down the block, they join the two the corner.  It's STANK and WEAZE, both 17.
Let me see it.
Let me see it.
(hands him the money) Where is it?
I can't carry it in my pocket, man.  And I can't go get it for you cause you might be a cop.  You gonna have to pick it up yourself.
Jason and Palmer aren't sure about this.  By the sphincte look on his face, Palmer would rather forget about it.
Don't worry.  It's just round the corner.  Halfway down that block, you can't miss it.  Top step of the front stairs, there's a loose stone.  Go on, I ain't shitting you.
Fuck it.  Alright.
They walk around the corner and enter a bleak block with least half the lots burnt out.
Is it too late for me to officially register my growing certainty that this is an extremely bad idea?

Farther down, in the center of one side of the street, st a particularly ominous abandoned building.  Bones' buildi Jason ignites a Zippo, and they see one loose brick.  Jas pulls it out and behind it sees a glint of baggy.
Easy as pie.  And twice as tasty.
He opens the bag.  It's filled with rock cocaine.

On the third floor, Shotgun sits in his straight-backed c in front of the open center window drinking coffee, cradl his rifle on his lap.  Sees the frat boys picking up thei shit.  Then he looks out at Bone's 'tomb': Dark blank windows staring back at him; the building's fr door covered with broken vertical boards with jagged piec missing, looking almost like a jack-o-lantern's grin. Shotgun then looks back down at the boys below.  From beh them they hear their car alarm go off.
Someone's screwing with the car!

But from the other way come cops, in a plain wrap car, a reaching out and putting the spinning blue light on the r No place to run.  No place to hide for the boys.  They re for the door of the shuttered building -- and it opens!
Yo.  You two, get the hell away from there!
But they ignore him and disappear into the darkness insid the gaping maw of Bones' building. Shotgun shakes his head sitting back down, cradling his rifle.
Fools.

Inside, the boys huddle in the darkness behind the door, waiting for the cops to pass. The boys look around the decayed Gothic interior lit only the eerie glow of the sodium vapor lights outside. What we last saw as the ornate 70's luxury lobby in Bones day, is now  a horror show. Walls torn and stained.  Mold grows in patches on the wal and ceiling.  Huge cobwebs hang.  The furniture's all bro A gnawing tearing sound makes Palmer spin: a rat sticks i head up through the rotted cushions of the couch.
Let's get the hell outta here.
Jason shushes him as the room is filled with the flashing blue light of the cop car trawling slowly down the street From inside they hear the sounds of a car door slamming a cop shoes walking.
Oh fuck, c'mon...

He gropes his way in the darkness to a staircase.  Palmer right behind him as they slip upstairs, deeper into the gaping darkness of the abandoned building. While below them the door opens and cop lights and cop vo penetrate the gloom.
...not going in there.  Waste o' time.
I saw 'em go in.
And from the boys' high vantage point up the stairs we se the first cop walk in with flashlight drawn.
All we see are two meaty hands unwrapping a wax-paper cov pork chop sandwich.  The cop, face in shadow, brings the ping sandwich up over his huge belly towards his face.
The frat boys hold their breath while rats run across the feet.  Jason slamming his hand over Palmer's mouth to kee him from screaming.
The young plainsclothes cop steps deeper into the room, a shines his flashlight at the stairwell.
Jason pulls the reluctant Palmer further up the stairs, t the third floor as below them they hear the cop coming up Jason pulls Palmer through the nearest door and into:
The rotted remains of what was once Jimmy Bones' master bedroom.  The room he was betrayed and slaughtered in.
The cop begins to head up the stairs.  Visible behind him down through the open front door, is the plain wrap car. older cop inside, mouth fulla sammich, loudly says:
Forget it!  No way they're in there.  Trust me.  I've been working down here twenty years.  No one goes in there.

We watch as the younger cop returns to the car, giving up And when he climbs in, we reverse and reveal who the olde cop is: LUPOVICH, the cop who helped kill Bones. But he's decayed and expanded into a Hank Quinlan-like mountain of corrupt cop flesh.  Too many pork chop sandwiches.
Let's get the hell outta here.
From upstairs, the boys see the blue light of the cop car recede as the car pulls away down below. Palmer reaches for the door.  He wants out.  But in the darkness, he can't find the door.
Gimme some light.

Behind Jason we see a shape, a shadow, a tall silhouette, man-shaped deeper darkness forming within the darkness. Jason lights his lighter.  And in the flickering we see behind him that this room now contains a portion of hell: It's not just the chipped paint and peeled rotted wall pa or the cracks and gaps in the broken old ceiling mirror. All surfaces seem to be a swirling, shifting pattern in w we can dimly and subliminally make out faces as if people were trapped on the surface of things.  Exactly like the glimpse we had beneath the world when Jimmy died... The floor, the walls, the furniture, everything in it -- out of the wracked and twisted devouring and devoured for of dead souls.  Their faces, hollow pleading eyes and how mouths visible like flowing grain in wood. And in the center of it all stands the dark silhouette of Bones, impossibly tall and thin, stretching malevolently across the room like a living shadow. But the boys don't see this as they're finding the door. see Bones shadow arching towards them while they fumble. Palmer finally opens the door to the sound of a deep rumb growl from the darkness on the other side.  And in the op door stands the black dog. They boys jump back.  But breathes easy.
Just a dog...

And the black dog leaps up at them -- teeth flying right the boys' throats.  And in the flickering ghastly light w see its demon face breaking through. The dog sinks his long teeth into Jason's arm.  He flails drops his lighter, still lit, on the floor. As soon as he does, the dog releases Jason, and disappear fast as it appeared, back into the darkness. The two kids panic, Jason shaking and bleeding, looking around, waiting for the dog or something else to attack, seeing back through the doorway into the room from hell. Behind them we see that tall man-shaped shadow.  The Bone shadow is oblivious to the two frantic boys, intent only the small flickering flame of the lighter still burning w it fell against the lower wood paneling of the wall. A thin trail of black smoke as the flame barely begins to catch on the chipped lead-filled flammable paint.

And stumble down the hall away from the horror, while bac the room the Bones-shadow watches as the lighter flickers dies out.  Other than a slightly blackened spot, the wall unburned. The black shadow shudders in rage, arches back and hooooo in frustration, its mouth abnormally large.  The shadowy snaps in the direction of the boys -- ready to vent it's wrath, and for a subliminal second we see in the head, th hellish face of Jimmy Bones. The boys round the second floor landing and fly down the flight of stairs.  Jason's foot breaks through a rotted floorboard and for a second, it appears as though rotten hands are just below stairs, grabbing at his foot and leg. He yelps in terror, pulling his foot back as they continu towards the front door, the Bones-thing's woofer-busting roaring down from the third floor.

Of pure horror and the desperation to survive drags the b off the stairs as they tear across the floor and hurl themselves out the front door into the night air... Jason falling and lying on the stoop.

Across the street, Shotgun sees the boys in the doorway.  Then, as a nearly dead vapor light suddenly flickers and comes to life, the shadows created on Bones' building mak look almost like a demonic face. Gulping for air, laughing hysterically at their survival, frat boys pause.  Jason sits back on his butt, checking h wound.  The doorway behind them just a black hole in spac
(bumping fists together) Damn, bro.  That was close!

Something - it happens so fast we're not sure just what g sucks-pulls Palmer back into the black doorway hole. Jason, still prone, tries to crawl away but whatever got friend now sucks him in too.  His fingernails scraping al the stoop in frenzied desperation.

When he hears the boys pitiful screams and whimpers from across the street, he leaps to his feet and tries to see the dark of the doorway across the street.  But he can on hear what is happening to the unlucky frat fellas: Moans and the sound of flesh torn, and swallowed, and the last dying screams.
The screaming reverberates.  Faces appear in some windows While in others, shades are drawn and the lights go out..
Mumbling to himself:
"For outside are dogs and sorcerers..." Revelation 22, vs. 15.
Tears welling in his eyes that he angrily flicks away.

It still has the shadowy look/shape of Jimmy Bones, now shifting again as the vapor light on the street sputters again, plunging the street into near darkness.  The body Palmer no longer visible below. When he looks back, the building seems just an old buildi again.  Then there's movement in an upper window, catchin his eye.  Shotgun sees the tall, shadowy silhouette. The figure is elongated, can't tell if it is a man, or th distorted shadow of a man.  It beckons to Shotgun.
Just tightens his grip on his rifle and speaks as if the shadowy thing across the street could hear him.
You still mad?  Still want me?  Come on and get me.
Shakes its head.  As if it can hear him.  And again mutel beckons to him.
Oh, right.  You can't.  You're trapped there.  Well ain't that too bad.  Ain't that just too damn bad.
This portion of the screenplay is originally pages 1-2. out of order to reflect the final film.
In the ghetto.  A thriving street.  Shops and apartments. Storefronts, newsstands.  Life in the hood. A sleek black Buick Electra 'deuce and a quarter' floats the avenue, Curtis Mayfield-style...

Behind the fur-covered steering wheel: SHOTGUN, a broke-n bodyguard for the man in the back seat: JIMMY BONES - 28.  His street.  His world.  Cool, handsom respected.  Dressed very fly, but not excessive.  Long bl coat, black silk shirt, and matching wide-brimmed hat. His left hand sports a big diamond ring while his right h toys with a long silver razor, polished and oiled to perfection so that the long glinting blade can swing back forth, or lock into position.
Bones steps out from the car on to his street like a benevolent feudal lord or a popular Mafia Don.

-- greeting and soul shaking every man, woman and child o the block: they display a mixture of fear/love and respec -- coolly taking down numbers in a notebook: soothing to losers, encouraging to the wary, tough with the welchers. -- and handing out a rare win to an astonished old man standing in his pajamas in the doorway of an old tenement
Don't spend it all in one place.  Spread it around.  And shop local.
This portion of the screenplay is originally pages 13-14. out of order to reflect the final film.   We see Pearl standing at the sink, scrubbing the blood st
on her, washing her hands, washing and washing them...

Her hands, washing becomes time passing.  Years, decades, building and the surroundings decay... And still the dark skinny dog prowls the shadows.  Just one more reason we n longer see anyone walk the street at night. The 90's end -- And Bones' building stands worn and naked with burnt-out on either side.  And the street feels like a ghost town. In the evil colored light of the gaseous street lights, Bones' own shadow stretches and distorts across all three stories.  His shadow face filling a window.  As in and ar the building and out in the ruins on either side, the bla dog still walks.

head_text.subj: AND FINALLY RETURN TO WEATHERED HANDS STILL WASHING

text: To the PRESENT. Pull out and reveal Pearl, skin drawn, eyes heavy, now 20 years older, washing her hands.  And then drying them.

This portion of the screenplay is originally pages 26-31. out of order to reflect the final film.  This portion of appear or occur elsewhere in the final movie.  In order t integrity of the screenplay, it has not been edited.

Two raging black screaming skulls engulfed in eye-scorchi fluorescent green fire: The decals on the front panel of a Gemini Executioner, a tech mixer.  Four hands at the controls.  Throbbing, shif twisted beats.  We're in a Northside dance club: Pull out to reveal BILL, 20, and MAURICE, aka Space Cowbo and Intergalactic Gangster of Love, 20.  The two boys DJ- They're accompanied by the crooning voice and dancing bod Bill's step-sister TIA, 29.  Bill's black.  Tia's white. Maurice is not of this earth. Bill's turntablizing: his hands dance between two competi style direct drive turntables tilted side by side, playin them like an instrument. While Maurice plays in and around and out of Bill's rhyth with his 6 top-loaded computerized CD players, the boys h the beat back and forth and up and down, building outrageously, till Maurice tips it over the top.
Goodness gracious grande bolas del fuego!

The floor is jammed with underground dance scenesters, college students and spaced-out shoegazers tripping on Ketamine, dancing with their invisible friends. The bar's surrounded by a sea of hands waving money, demanding drinks.  Our boys are popular.  And the club is making a lot of green tonight. See someone checking out all the money, counting heads: PATRICK, 23, Bill's older brother.  The money man.
Stank and Weaze are cruising around in the frat boys BMW, laughing their asses off.
Live show's over.  And a chill mix tape plays while the b pack their gear.  Across the club, Patrick's arguing with club owner, MOE.  Just now handing Patrick a couple bills Patrick's not happy.
The guys and Tia stumble out with all their equipment, loading it and themselves into Patrick's over-sized SUV.  Patrick right behind them.  They gather around to split t fee.
Well, the bad news is we only made 25 bucks each.
How could that be?  The box was packed!
Moe's terms.
We practically paying him for the privilege of playing his club.
So what the hell's the good news?
I just accelerated my top secret long term plan for our world domination.

Sqweeep.  We innerup this programme to bring you this special news bulletin -- (human teletype sounds) "Aliens from Reticula 3 have hijacked Patrick Peet and injected moly headcheese into his skull filling his entire brain cavity with cosmic slop..."
I was planning on waiting until I got the place cleaned out, but -- like the man says, carpe diem.
Patrick hands Bill and Tia each a flyer: The Restaurant Brothers Ill Bill and DJ Maurice -- a.k.a. The Space Cowboy Playing at Illibent.  Fridays.
Illibent?  Who's club is that?
Ours!
What're ya talkin' about, OURS?
Patrick beckons them into the car.

Patrick pulls up to the abandoned lot next to Bones' building.  In broad daylight the building looks even stranger.  The lines don't matchup.  Weeds and broken gla rusted autoparts, and empty abandoned shopping carts in tangled heaps like ruins in the lot beside the building.
Looks like a damn graveyard round here.
I'm telling you, this neighborhood is coming back.
Yeah.  But just where the hell has it been?
They step up to the front of the building.
Damn.  That is the ugliest building I have ever seen.
Naw.  I think it's... I dunno.  Something about it just buzzes me.
That would be the after effects of that Reticular inseminoid encounter you had.
Patrick opens the door and steps inside.
Welcome to the Ill Zone.

The darkness broken only by sunlight streaming through gr windows reveals the decaying interior of the building. We can see now nothing's been moved since the late '70's. Old furniture, carpets, pictures - late '70's Gothic.
Damn it's cold in here!
It's eighty degrees outside.  And it's gotta be barely fifty in here.
And damp, too.  Let's not forget damp.
Whattaya think?  Can you picture it?  Over there the bar, and in here -- the dance floor.
Possible...maybe...could be.
Patrick leads them to the stairwell going up and down aro the old elevator cage/shaft.
I got a great deal on it.  They couldn't give this place away.  Just dead meat stanking up their books for twenty years.
They come to the elevator shaft, no elevator in sight.
The last owner on the lease before the bank was back in '79.  Some dude named Jimmy Bones.  Empty ever since.
Maurice looks down the elevator shaft and gets immediatel dizzy, almost plunging to his doom - pulled back by Bill.
Jimmy Bones?
Yeah, you heard of him?
You haven't?
Not that I remember.
He was a local legend back in the '70's.  There was a song, Stagolee kinda deal: "This is the ballad of Jimmy Bones/Black as night and hard as stone..."
I was born near here.  My dad's from here.  He never mentioned it.
Bones!  How baddass is zat?  This is the place for us.  Patrick, you get platinum props, man.  Platinum.
Yeah, in the land of the blind the one eye'd are king.
What's your problem with Crippled Dick?
Look around, this place is a dump!  Naw, it'd have to work to be a dump.
You gotta use your imagination.
"This is Patrick..."  (makes the sound of egg cracking, the sizzling as it lands in the skillet) "...And this is Patrick on crack."  Imagination, my butt.  Even the space cowboy can't...
(interrupting) Why don't y'all check out the rest?  I'm going downstairs and see if I can get the furnace fired up.  Warm this place up, you'll see.  It has serious potential.
Potential toxic dump site.
Mia, Bill and Maurice all climb the stairs as Maurice lig a joint with a little box of stick matches.
Are you nuts?

The man said just to use my imagination.   (takes a huge hit) Let's see...yeah, I get it.  Potential.  I can see it now.  The first major urban theme park.  Village Ghetto land.  Kinda like Legoland, but made entirely from broken glass, hypodermic needles and crack vials.  Totally E-ticket.
Keep smokin', fool.
Tia checks out the second floor while Bill and Maurice continue up the stairs to the third floor.  Bones' old cr
Behind them, barely subliminal glimpse - a manshaped dark shadow within a shadow.  Bill feels a cold wind from nowh And hears a whispery sound seemingly carried in the breez
It ain't eh money.  It's the big fat floating what if...
What did you say?
I didn't say nothing.
Take him down to the storm clear.  Bury him.
You didn't hear that?  "Take him... " Something.  "Bury him" or...
Take who where?  What you smokin'?
Tia's checking out a bedroom.  Hears a light tinkling in closet.  She opens it: empty except a row of rusty metal hangers, holding the moldy remains of Bones old suits.

Is there a flashlight, poking around.  Trying to find the metal knob to turn on the gas.  Eerie as hell down there. Out of the corner of our eyes we see a shadow moving, looming.  A scurrying sound and Patrick turns his flashli in the other direction: we glimpse a bloated rat. Behind him, the shadow we glimpsed grows, elongates.  Pat notes another door.  This one padlocked.  Sensing someone something behind him, Patrick turns with the flashlight. Nothing there.  But the Bones-shadow is behind him again. Again he feels something and again he turns the flashligh around: nothing. Except the Bones-shadow is again...behind him. Shaking it off, Patrick heads for the old heater, pulling matches to light the pilot as Bones-shadow stays behind h

Bones watches as Patrick reaches around the gas heater. Patrick strikes a match head, the Bones-shadow moves even closer to him as Patrick reaches in and lights the pilot. When Patrick steps back, Bones-shadow grows and stretches spreading like an ink stain, reaching across to where the pilot flame flickers. In profile, the shadow-mouth blows...but no breath comes The flame doesn't even flicker. Bones tilts his head back and lets loose an eerie bellow frustration in a subliminal flash we see a howling mouth, bigger than any human mouth, howling within the shadow-fa The sound echoes all through the basement rooms as Patric walks back upstairs.  He slaps a nearby plumbing pipe.
Go on old pipes, groan all you like.  Just please don't burst.  That I can't afford.
As disappointed in whatever he hoped blowing out the furn pilot would do, he steps into the rusted remains of the o elevator and the POV begins to levitate.
Bones' POV rises straight up as if still in a working elevator.  It rises and we follow up from the basement to empty first floor, past the second floor to:

Where we're still inside, floating in the elevator cage.  Then the POV moves through the metal bars and floats towa Bill, who's approaching the door of the room where Jimmy died. As Bill reaches to open it, Bones' POV floats closer - an closer - right up on Bill's back now.  Bill feeling the h on his neck suddenly rising.  Then he hears:
Go on.  It won't kill you.
Bill turns around to check with Maurice.
You had to hear tha...
But Maurice is gone.  And he doesn't see the shadow there behind him.  Bill leans in to the door, listening...
I ain't gonna be the only one with this nigger's blood on my hands...
What the f--?
A hand jolts him from behind.  He spins -- it's just Maur
'S up?
Nothing.  Contact paranoia.  Must be buggin' from hanging with you.

They turn to walk back down.  Maurice stops to re-light h joint when the Bones-shadow reaches out to grab his wrist But it's no good.  The shadow hand passes right through, Maurice pauses for an instant as if he felt something. Maurice lights his roach, and the match burns closer and closer to his fingertips.  Then singes them and he drops match.  Maurice then heads downstairs after Bill. The shadow remains behind, staring at the still burning m on the wooden floor.  He bends down, staring intently as willing it to burn, his hands urging it on, the flame suddenly rising.  But then the match sputters harmlessly The shadow turns back towards the boys downstairs.

Tia explores the rest of the floor.  Hears a sound, like whimpering, from behind another door. She slowly eases open the door then jumps back -- Inside, dog.  It growls low and mean, the black fur on the back o it's neck rising.  It's eyes burning too red and bright. Tia freezes. The dog growls deeply at her.  And as he does we see the Bones shadow rising behind her.  It seems to lean in and her, and the dog stops growling. Tia cautiously holds her hand outstretched with the burge for the dog to smell. Bones' shadow from lingers behind her, perhaps simply enjoying the first sight in hellish eons of a beautiful g
How'd you get locked in here?  And for how long?  Poor baby...
The dog leaps up - but not to rip her throat out.  Instea snatches the burger and wolfs it down in one gulp.
Poor boy.  You must be starving.
Bill looks skeptical, Maurice outraged.  Patrick firm.
You want us to move in here?
That's the only way we'll get the place fixed up in time.
Yeah right, and which ever of us is still alive at the end of the week inherits all Vincent Price's cash.
Look, you guys want to play college radio, high school reunions, and some fool's club once a week for the rest of your lives, that's cool.  But I think we can do better.
You soundin' like the old man now.

I believe in you guys.  You are the real shit.  And you know it.  Now I'm putting everything I got into this cuz I think we can make it happen, but you gotta put a little in too.  Now all I"m asking is that everybody do their part.  We'll move some shit in, and take shifts, or all crash together here --
Pat's right.  It'll be fun.
Yeah, fine.  But Mars Needs Women.  If I gotta sleep in a spookhouse, surround me with chicks who are more scared than me.  Speaking of which...
Tia's coming down the stairs.  Maurice watching her legs appreciatively as she descends.
(rips Maurice's skull) Tia ain't a chick.  She's family.  And don't forget it.
Let's get going.  Go home, pick up what we need, then crash here.
Look who I found.
She comes in with the dog padding silently behind her.
Damn, that's the nastiest dog I ever seen.  Nothin' but skin and bones.
Yeah, call his skinny ass "Bones."
"Bones" grins, all teeth with its tongue hanging out.  Th walk out the front door, the dog slipping out with them.
Shotgun watches from the window as the group exits the building with the dog.  Seeing the cur he instinctively reaches for his gun.  But the dog's surrounded by kids.
Hey, watcha doing with that dog?
He yours, sir?
Hell no!
Then what do you care?
Take my advice.  And shoot that dog.  Or let me.
Alright.  Yes sir.  Anything you say.

Tia, Bill and Bones the dog pile into the van as Pearl an her daughter CINNABAR, 21, walk by. The daughter's as fine now as her mother was then.  Pearl sees the dog in the van and her head snaps to the gang.
Don't feed that dog.
You people really don't like dogs.
Some holes can't be filled.  Some hungers can't be satisfied.
(way under his breath) And some people need their medication tweaked.
I'm not joking boy.  Don't feed it.  It'll only make it hungrier.

Pearl walks a little faster, trying to draw Cinnabar away from the kids and the dog.  But Cinnabar lingers a few paces behind her mother and catches Patrick's eye.  He's stunned, and before he can speak, Maurice speaks for him.
Need any help with those bags, Ma'am?
No thanks.
no really, let us help.  We're new in the neighborhood, gonna be neighbors.
You moved into this block?
Not really to live, just to play.
That building?
Gonna be le hot shit.   (to Pearl) Pardon my Francais.  Dance club.  The Resurrection Brothers play there.  Heard of them?
Should I?
Are they on the radio?
Naw.  But they will be.  They're the best.
How do you know?
I manage them.
And you bought the building?
Pearl studies their faces, especially Patrick's.
You look mighty familiar to me.  You sure you're not from around here?
